messages.content: I've ran in to this before but forget the fix, can we try to explain here for anyone else experiencing this?
who are you using as a fee payer? and what permissions does that account have for send?

`Fee_payer_not_permitted_to_send` error happens if the Send permission in fee payer account account is set to Proof and the fee payment is authorized using signatures (all fee payments currently are authorized using signatures) - from Deepthi.

The current simple fix is use a different fee payer. Gregor proposed this RFC https://github.com/o1-labs/zkapp-cli/issues/129 that explains the issue in more detail in the `Incompatible with permissions` section.

> I'm just wondering what is the proper usage to interact with the smart contract if I can't use the generated address from zk deploy?

Current workaround would be to generate a different (non zkapp) account / keypair, fund it from the faucet, and use it everywhere as the fee payer
@CalebCurry ^
Thanks!! Is there a specific command / process to generate a key pair?

@gregor or set permissions send: signature in your zkapp?

or add a @method to pay the required fee amount from the balance of the zkapp with balance.subInPlace(amount) which can be proven

> or set permissions send: signature in your zkapp?
yes fair enough

> or add a @method to pay the required fee amount from the balance of the zkapp
no, you still need a non-zkapp fee payer on every tx

> or set permissions send: signature in your zkapp?
but then you can't use the zkapp to deal with MINA in a permissionless way

ah sorry you need `toBase59()` on the privatekey (going to fix that...)
```ts
console.log(JSON.stringify({ privateKey: privateKey.toBase58(), publicKey }))
```
why cant you use a zkapp as a fee payer? bcs Mina.transaction does the AU from the public key set as fee payer for you?
if yes, i think this should be changed, because i already have several features in the pipeline for a zkapp fee payer
it's a complex topic, the protocol doesn't allow fee paying with proofs, there was an attempt to make that work but complications arose so it was decided that this doesn't make the HF
https://github.com/MinaProtocol/mina/pull/11649
not going to land soon ^
okay thanks

Gregor do you know what the limitation there is exactly? If I read the sourcecode correctly, the "feepayer" object essentially gets converted into an AccountUpdate for the Mina Circuit anyways, so wouldn't it be pretty trivial to do that?
it's not a difficulty of implementing, but of resolving attack vectors that arise when fee paying can be authorized with a proof

roughly this @rpanic  @maht0rz :

* when transactions are accepted into the mempool, the fee is deducted from the fee payer account. _Regardless_ of whether the transaction eventually makes it into a block. this is important to defend against DDoS -- there has to be a cost to spamming the network with transactions, and you can't bypass that cost by making the tx invalid
* to make this clear: when an invalid txs get into the mempool, the fee will be lost for the fee paying account, but the _rest of the tx will not be applied_
* the mempool can't check preconditions validity on incoming tx. that's because the value of these preconditions only gets decided when the tx is put into a block. so, you can make txs invalid and their invalidity can't be detected at the point when txs are accepted & the fee is deducted

* now assume you have a zkApp that allows to pay fees with proofs. given the two points above, there is no way you can prevent the following attack:
    - someone sends a large number of txs with your zkApp as fee payer. the txs have valid proofs but are invalid because of failing preconditions
    - each of those txs will drain the fee from your zkApp account, but since the rest of the tx is not applied, there is no way for you to "get something back" in return for the fee within the body of the tx (which would have been a common pattern of fee paying zkApps)
    - so, someone who doesn't like you will definitely be able to burn all the funds in your zkApp account, 0.1 MINA by 0.1 MINA

I was challenged to provide use cases for fee paying zkApps that would justify implementing a half-baked version, with those vulnerabilities. In the end we all agreed that the most important use cases can't be implemented with this limitation and we decided that it doesn't make the hard fork

that said, this feature would have been a "late addition" anyway. we didn't have (or want to take) the time to redesign parts of the protocol to mitigate those attacks. the protocol is basically frozen since 1-2 months. but I'm sure another HF will provide opportunity to enhance zkApps further. also, we don't want future hard forks to be this big and slow and complicated 😄
i havent taken a look at the PR, but how do you prevent the attack vector you mentioned where the fee payer AU is always applied?
the PR doesn't prevent it, this was discovered later
could be like an extra property on the AU, which will mark it as a fee payer / always applied, then it could be explicitly issued from the zkapp
the case i’m looking to implement is to allow paying the fee in a custom token

Wow that actually makes a lot of sense, thanks gregor!
I also can't think of any fix to that. For me it now also becomes clear why, for example ethereum, doesn't allow fee payment with smartcontracts. 
The only reasonable precondition you can (also also do) effectively check is the nonce, because you can check that against the mempool easily, and replace txs with higher fees if two txs collide. 
But if you have other dynamics it gets increasingly harder to mitigate this ddos vector

No because the feepayer AU might depend on other AUs succeeding. And if they don't, the feepayer is invalid.
You would habe to restrict the feepayer AU to be on calldepth 0 which defeat a lot of purpose
i meant something rather simple where the counterpart token AU would have to be simple but yeah, looks like an interesting design problem

@gregor @maht0rz is there a step I can take to change the fee payer for deployment?

`zk deploy` gives:
  Failed to send transaction to relayer. Errors: Couldn't send zkApp command: ["Fee_payer_not_permitted_to_send"] 

I generated a new account with the code above, but unsure how to configure that to redeploy the smart contract...

Hey @CalebCurry ! There's no way you can configure `zk deploy` to get past that, redeploying is currently only possible with a custom deploy script. Good news: we have lined up the mentioned update to the zkapp CLI  to be implemented next week https://github.com/o1-labs/zkapp-cli/issues/129. With this, the CLI will let you use a different fee payer

I'm not understand what is this error: Fee_payer_not_permitted_to_send, I find only one of my accounts(berkeley) can send test mina without this error, but all others give me this error: `Couldn't send user command: ["Fee_payer_not_permitted_to_send"]`
Is there any explanation about the concept of fee payer?
PS: I'm using `Auro Wallet` for above sending.

@garethtdavies appreciate all the help. I still feel there is some confusion around this topic or the error `Fee_payer_not_permitted_to_send` is not clear. Do you have a suggested path to fix the problem for @icerdesign here?

I think it's as simple as by default when deploying a zkApp the permission for `send` is `proof` ref https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/advanced-snarkyjs/permissions#default-permissions. The fee can only be paid via a signature (detailed explanation by Gregor above) hence the error when using the same address for a fee payer as the deployed zkApp.

So, you can either change the permissions on the zkApp to allow sending via signature e.g. `proofOrSignature` (not ideal) or use a different fee payer that does not have send permissions set to `proof` - there is a PR linked above that allows the CLI to do this. You can confirm the permissions of the zkApp on an explorer or via GraphQL.
